data.title: The find widget should use aria-hidden when it is hidden
data.body:
For example, in the Insiders on Windows

* Open an empty editor (with the find widget collapsed)
* Open Help > Accessibility Options
* Turn accessibility on
* Click to show accessibility tree
* Get it out into a file to inspect it
* Observe the find widget being in the accessibility tree even if it is hidden:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/26675378/f943c460-46c3-11e7-83c0-47ee6ca5ac8d.png)

data.title: Inconsistent representation of 'this' when debugging javascript
data.body:
It seems that the debugger is converting lambda/arrow functions into regular anonymous functions which has a different `this` context. So it's not a true representation of the context at runtime.

![screen shot 2017-06-01 at 10 39 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4884262/26673967/a4817f42-46b6-11e7-84f1-3899e5d0e8cf.png)

![screen shot 2017-06-01 at 09 36 19](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4884262/26674033/d13126dc-46b6-11e7-94cf-551bedf4abf3.png)

![screen shot 2017-06-01 at 09 36 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4884262/26675040/45276a9e-46ba-11e7-9881-1bf224c85c99.png)

By changing the inner lambda function to a regular `function() {}` in the code above it works as expected.

Similar issue to this https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6866 only it effects ES6 not just Typescript.

----

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Mac OSX (Sierra - 10.12.3)
- Nodejs Version: 8.0.0

Note:
Debugging with legacy protocol because Node.js v7.7.1 was detected.
node --debug-brk=11009 --nolazy src/index.js

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a function scope.
2. Inside the function declare a lambda function which uses `this` inside it.
3. Ensure you call the lambda
3. Put a breakpoint inside the lambda function
4. `this` in the locals/debug window is showing the inner anonymous function scope where as in the actual runtime; `this` is referring to the outer function scope (like it should in lambda functions)

data.title: Defining own variables in tasks.json
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.5 & Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

I've set up a tasks.json file for building a project on multiple platforms. All platforms see the same content of the project repository. This is done either via disk sharing, because of running another platform in a VM, or via sync with the Git repository. So far so good, they all see the same task.json. However some command lines are rather long and those long lines are identical for most part. For example:

`"rm -rf build; mkdir build; cd build; ../configure --with-bash-malloc=no CFLAGS=\"-O3 -fno-builtin-malloc -fno-builtin-calloc -fno-builtin-realloc -fno-builtin-free\" LDFLAGS=-L/usr/local/lib LIBS=\"-ltcmalloc -lcurl\" CC=clang`

Similar lines are there for the different platforms. The configure part is always the same for the different platforms, so it would be nice to factor out this common part. Thus the question is if it is possible to define your own variables, so you can use them similar to ${workspaceRoot}.

Thus define somewhere

```
"win_dir": "build_windows",
"linux_dir": "build",
"osx_dir": "build_osx",
"configure": "../configure --with-bash-malloc=no CFLAGS=\"-O3 -fno-builtin-malloc -fno-builtin-calloc -fno-builtin-realloc -fno-builtin-free\" LDFLAGS=-L/usr/local/lib LIBS=\"-ltcmalloc -lcurl\" CC=clang"
```
And then write

```
"tasks": [
    {
        "taskName": "configure",
        "command": "bash",
        "windows": {
            "args": ["-c", "rm -rf ${win_dir}; mkdir ${win_dir}; cd ${win_dir}; ${configure}"]
        },
        "linux": {
            "args": ["-c", "rm -rf ${linux_dir}; mkdir ${linux_dir}; cd ${linux_dir}; ${configure}"]
        },
        "osx": {
            "args": ["-c", "rm -rf ${osx_dir}; mkdir ${osx_dir}; cd ${osx_dir}; ${configure}"]
        },
        "isBuildCommand": true,
        "problemMatcher": "$make-compile"
    },
    ... others tasks using the variables
```
When making changes to the build directory or arguments passed to configure etc, then the tasks.json file needs only editing at one place, instead of many.

Perhaps it is already possible but I'm unable to find out how. I tried to do something with the declares block, but that seems to be hard tied to problemMatcher. You can find some examples, but I could not find clear documentation of of the elements of the tasks.json file and how they interact.

Perhaps I'm missing something, please educate me!

While at it, some sort of macro expansion would be nice also.
that would allow e.g.
"configure_cmd_line($1)": "rm -rf ${$1}; mkdir ${$1}; cd ${$1}; ${configure}"

and the args part would then become:
```
...
"linux": {
            "args": ["-c", "configure_cmd_line(${linux_dir})"]
        },
...
```
I do not care so much about the actual syntax, as long as it is possible to factor out common used patterns that repeat themselves in the tasks.json file, especially with multi platform builds. That would make it much more easier to maintain and copy them from one project to another and only slightly modify them in at least as possible places as possible.

data.title: VS Code's Source control doesn't show controls
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Creator Update v1703 b15063.332

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Don't have git in any place in Windows
2. Activate and setup Linux subsystem for Windows (git, node, npm etc)
3. Use Bash in VS Code on Windows

Looks like this:
![2017-06-01_18-16-43](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12271104/26673157/d6fb6b46-46f6-11e7-851e-9c3ee96bcfe5.png)

Desctiption:
After I switched to Bash on Ubuntu on Windows and moved all of my tools in Linux subsystem, Source Contol section in VS Code doesn't show any controls. I uninstalled git from Windows, removed it from PATH. I use Bash in VS Code on my Windows and every tool works, but this bug disturbs me.

I set Bash here, but VS Code doesn't catch git from Linux subsystem
```
"terminal.external.windowsExec": "C:\\Windows\\sysnative\\bash.exe",
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\sysnative\\bash.exe"
```


In devtools, it says: `/E:/Program Files (x86)/Visual Studio Code/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:29 [Extension Host] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\Users\Kenya-West\AppData\Local\GitHub'`

Any solution or a workaround for this?

data.title: eslint constantly compains about no-use-before-define rule
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open [spodr](https://github.com/fairmanager/spodr) in VS Code

ESLint shows an alert saying: `d:\spodr\.eslintrc`: Configuration for rule "no-use-before-define" is invalid: Value "[object Object]" no (or more than one) schemas match.

The rule is defined as:
```json
		"no-use-before-define": [
			2,
			{
				"functions": false,
				"classes": true,
				"variables": true
			}
		],
```

When I run eslint manually from the CLI, I get no errors and behavior in general is as expected.

data.title: Confusing TypeScript mismatch error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2

I am some questions regarding this error message:

> Version mismatch! global tsc (2.3.2) != VS Code's language service (2.3.4). Inconsistent compile errors might occur

This appears in a project where I have instructed VSCode to use the workspace version of TypeScript, 2.3.4.

I don't understand what is meant by "global tsc" and "VS Code's language service".

- When I change the "TypeScript version" in the VSCode UI, what is this changing? (It seems to be changing "VS Code's language service".)
- What exactly is "global tsc"? Can I change the version of that, too?

I have found myself reading the ["more information" guide](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/typescript#_using-newer-typescript-versions) multiple times, but each time I never understand what I should do. I don't want to dismiss the message, in case this version mismatch does actually cause me problems. Maybe we can improve the messaging.

data.title: JavaScript Intellisense Request
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:
(JavaScript)
1. Create variable function
```js
var MyClass = function(){
  var self = this;
  self.foo= "";
  this.bar = "";
}
```

The intellisense will note that `bar` is a property of `MyClass` but not `foo`.
This being due to `self` not being recognised as a reference to `this` (MyClass).

This is a common way of writing Knockout code or if you are working with multiple nested models using this design pattern is very useful.

I would think that the intellisense would pick this up, but at the moment it does not.

data.title: Welcome page customise links text is cut when 3 extensions are already installed

Should we adapt to the text length somehow, or maybe shorten `(installed)` to a check mark () or something similar as a quick fix?

data.title: TypeScript language service dies after 5 times updating 'typescript.npm' to the wrong value
data.body:
Testing #27695

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Follow testing steps as in #27695.
2. Try to set `typescript.npm` to different values that do not exist.
Observe how the 'could not install typings' notification appears. After 5th time of setting it to the wrong value the following notification appears:

> "The TypeScript language service died 5 times right after it got started. The service will not be restarted."

However, if I set it in to the correct value on the sixth time, I successfully get typings for JQuery. 

Repeating the steps above again leads to "The TypeScript language service died 5 times right after it got started. The service will not be restarted." second time (without restarting VS Code).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2239563/26669179/2ddd039c-46ad-11e7-8d12-8d7d3728fdc2.png)

As a user I would be happy not to receive the message about the dead service in this case (as it still restarts after 6th time?).

data.title: Link detection in output channel seems occasionally broken
data.body:
Filenames in output channels used to be clickable and one could open the target files and jump to line/column but doesn't work anymore in latest release 1.12.2 on Mac. 

E.g.
 
```javascript
let out = vscode.window.createOutputChannel('whatever')
out.appendLine ('ERROR: ... '+ e)
```
Would have rendered to a clickable link like:

```
ERROR: ... at /some/filenames/catalog.cds:47:11
```

Actually, this used to work in some past release. Stopped working in some later update. Worked again for a short time in 1.12.0 and gone again in 1.12.1 or .2. Looks like a pattern meanwhile.

data.title: [uncaught exception]: [object Object] in console when creating jsconfig.json via message

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. open an empty folder
2. add a index.js file
3. trigger "go to project configuration"

=> `[uncaught exception]: [object Object]` shows up in the console

Looks like there is a call to `fileService.doResolveTextContent` that results in an error promise which is not handled.
